2. "The truck was blue" - This is a statement that affirms Q, the consequent of the conditional statement.

To determine if we can logically infer "The car was red" (P), we need to examine the relationship between the conditional statement and the affirmation of Q.

In a conditional statement, the truth of Q does not necessarily imply the truth of P. This is because the conditional statement only guarantees that if P is true, then Q must be true, but it does not provide any information about the truth of P when Q is true.

In this case, we know that Q is true (the truck was blue), but we cannot conclude that P must be true (the car was red) solely based on this information. There might be other reasons why the truck was blue, unrelated to the color of the car.
